results.title: Tuvalu
results.creator_credit: Denmark, U-V Film and Video and Leif Stubkjaer,
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Oceans of Dreams - Currents of Change Series”.
Tuvalu has no rivers, no natural forests, scant soil cover and at its highest point is only 5 metres above sea level. The film looks at contemporary Tuvalu, the old ways, the new challenges and how people live.

results.title: Vanuatu
results.creator_credit: Denmark, U-V Film and Video and Leif Stubkjaer,
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Oceans of Dreams - Currents of Change Series”.
A look at contemporary Vanuatu with its contrasts of almost undisturbed traditional areas, to the sophisticated capital, Port Vila.

results.title: Kiribati
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Oceans of Dreams - Currents of Change Series”.
Kiribati becomes an independent nation in 1979. The Republic comprises 33 coral atolls, formerly the Gilbert, Phoenix and Line Island groups. The atolls are often no more than a few metres above sea level, extremely narrow and with scant soil and surface water. Kiribati’s 719 square kilometres must support a population of approximately 65,000. What the land lacks in natural resources is compensated for by a vast ocean economic zone (3 million square kilometres), straddling the equator and stretching from near Hawaii in the North to Tuvala and Fiji in the south. The film looks at contemporary and traditional life, the challenges and changes which this Republic faces today.

results.title: Cook Islands
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Oceans of Dreams - Currents of Change Series”.
The Cook Islands are a collection of small coral atolls spread over a vast area of the South Pacific Ocean. They are inhabited by Polynesian Maoris who are closely linked to New Zealand Maoris. The Cook Islands’ other links with New Zealand are economic and political. Once a protectorate of New Zealand, the Cook Islands are now self-governing but their people are citizens of New Zealand. More of them now live there than in their home islands. A cultural renaissance is taking place in the Cooks, partly encouraged by tourism, the education system and by the wishes of the people. This is but one of the issues and changes which the film examines in a contemporary account of life in these islands.

results.title: Observation
results.brief_description: The space station Observation is twirling through the cosmos, the power cut and the crew missing. Players must help solve the mystery by taking control of SAM (Systems Administration Maintenance), the station’s AI software that’s based on HAL from Stanley Kubrick’s 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968).

constellations_primary.name: Evil AI, dystopias and production design
constellations_primary.description: In No Code’s sci-fi thriller players take command of a multi-national space station’s artificial intelligence system to help the sole survivor solve the mystery of a missing crew and why the station is wildly off course.

results.description:
The space station Observation is twirling through the cosmos, the power cut and the crew missing. The station’s lone occupant is Dr Emma Fisher, who players must help solve the mystery by taking control of SAM (Systems Administration Maintenance), the station’s AI software that’s based on HAL from Stanley Kubrick’s 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968). This sci-fi thriller draws inspiration from many similar interstellar-set horror stories and puts players in command of a potentially malevolent AI.

The developers were intrigued by the question of whether AI could even be evil or if its code had somehow failed it. Observation players get to explore that idea, and their actions as SAM affect the game world and story.

results.title: You are what you eat
results.creator_credit: Becky Bristow, William C. Crain and Barr Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Nutrition”.
Animated sequences explore this theme, while two voices discuss the significance of each scene. They explain the importance of choosing food from all of the basic food groups to provide a balanced diet. They also explain how proteins, carbohydrates, fats, vitamins, and minerals are used in our bodies, how digestion changes the food we eat so our bodies can use the nutrients, and how exercise and rest are needed to help us grow strong and healthy.

results.title: You are what you eat
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Nutrition”.
Six lively programs hosted by Liza Goddard which offer information and practical advice on how to dramatically improve health by altering eating habits. Although aimed at British adults the programs are short and pacy and very relevant to Australian adolescents and adults. The contents are: “Food for life: how to include more fibre, fruit, vegetables and fish”, “Go with the grain: re-educating children to eat more grain”, “Don’t eat your heart out: reducing fats in the diet”, “Sweet nothing: try to eliminate sugar which provides no nourishment”, “Pinch of chemicals: manufactured goods contain additives, preservatives and salt”, “Food in the fast lane: simple suggestions for nourishing packed lunches and fast foods”.

results.title: Coping with death
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, Helen Gaynor, Alfred Hospital and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Nurses”.
Nurses “was filmed by four nurses and their friends at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne to capture the real life drama of nursing from a very different perspective…their own” Nurses are: Kerryn O’Rourke - Oncology. Trish Builic - Psychiatric (to the homeless). Jane Newham - Emergency. Cassie Steward - Theatre. Ep 3: This episode examines the kind of thoughts and coping mechanisms the nurses have developed in a job that obviously has a high mortality rate. And in particular reflects upon the naivete of the ‘I am going to be a nurse to help people’ idea that all four women have had to deal with. This episode elaborates upon a patient relationship that we have already seen Kerryn commit to. She talks about the way she has necessarily become more detached and that some days, especially with staff shortages the physical side of nursing of observing patients and administering medication means that you just don’t have the ability to feel sad. And that the flip side to this is that ultimately patients appreciate the kindness, understanding and sensitivity given by nurses not if they got their medication on time. Trish talks about the sense of emotions being at either end of the spectrum, that when someone commits suicide or an assault occurs it’s a big jolt in reminding her how crucial the job is. Jane talks about the ‘controlled voice’ she finds herself using when something really serious is happening.

results.title: Is there life after death?
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, Helen Gaynor, Alfred Hospital and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Nurses”.
Nurses “was filmed by four nurses and their friends at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne to capture the real life drama of nursing from a very different perspective…their own” Nurses are: Kerryn O’Rourke - Oncology. Trish Builic - Psychiatric (to the homeless). Jane Newham - Emergency. Cassie Steward - Theatre. Ep 4. With Christmas and the Millenium coming up there are conclusions and last comments. There are holidays taken, shopping to be done and religion and beliefs are reflected upon. Jane demystifies the bed pan. One of Kerryn’s patients has rapidly deteriorated. Cassie becomes a patient. And Trish gets frustrated at the outpouring of good will on Christmas day and wonders where it all goes for the rest of the year.
